content.description: A researcher measured the temperature at which two different samples of double-stranded <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> denature (separate into single strands). Sample <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> denatured at a significantly lower temperature than sample <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> did. Based on the data, the researcher claims that the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in sample <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> is composed of a higher percentage of guanine and cytosine than the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in sample <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is.
content.question: Which of the following best supports the researcher’s claim?

choices.label: The bonds between guanine and cytosine are covalent bonds, which require more energy to disrupt than those between adenine and thymine.
Guanine-cytosine pairs denature at a higher temperature because they have more hydrogen bonds between them than adenine-thymine pairs do.
Adenine-thymine pairs require less energy to separate because adenine and thymine are both single-ring bases.
Guanine-cytosine pairs require more energy to separate because one is a purine and one is a pyrimidine.

content.answer: Guanine-cytosine pairs denature at a higher temperature because they have more hydrogen bonds between them than adenine-thymine pairs do.
